Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cannulation Strategies in Aortic Arch Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either right axillary or innominate artery cannulation.

Participants.evidence: Conducted across six Canadian centers, this randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing proximal aortic arch surgery. Eligibility criteria encompassed patients with ATAAD.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were assigned to right axillary artery cannulation (intervention) or innominate artery cannulation (control).

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare the efficacy of right axillary and innominate artery cannulation strategies for cerebral protection.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of new severe ischemic lesions, evaluated through diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation concealment was achieved using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 222 participants were randomised, with 111 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis followed an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of new severe ischemic lesions was comparable between the axillary group (34%) and the innominate group (38.8%).

Harms.evidence: Thirty-day mortality rates and adverse events, including seizures and delirium, were similar across both groups.
